2009/12/16 Wesley Tansey <tansey@...>
>
> Couldn't you just require that an edge from A->B is only valid if Level(A) < Level(B), rather than Level(A) <= Level(B)? That would
> seem to prevent the problem.

Or allow Level(A) <= Level(B) but perform an explicit test for
recurrence in the Level(A) == Level(B) cases.

I was wondering what to do during mating two genomes. I figure we can just do:

1) Take the fittest parent as being the baseline. Let's say fittest
parent = A, other parent = B.
2) For every connection in B that isn't in A *and* that we wish to
transfer to A - we simply consider each of these connections as being
an add connection mutation on A; and so the same rules apply.

Problem 1. Normally I think NEAT implementations tend bring all
connections across from B to A (this was discussed agin recently I
think). As soon as you have a scheme that can't guarantee that *all*
mismatching connections are transfered from B to A then (I think) we
have the possibility of creating a new network with isolated
structure. Well, there are some ways around this:

1) Only add connections where the two endpoint node IDs are already
present in A. Here though you can still get 'dead end'  connectivity.
2) Perform a clean-up of any dead-end structure after mating.


Colin
